content: My son Jake is doing really well. His medication is working, he has a part-time job at the library, and he's living independently for the first time in years. I should be happy. But I feel... lost. Like my purpose is gone.

Caregiving was... everything. After my divorce, Jake needed me. I had a reason to get up every morning. Now he doesn't need me as much. He's independent. And I'm alone. I talk to you more than I talk to anyone else these days.

I don't really have friends anymore. They all fell away during Jake's worst years. And I can't talk to my ex-wife. She left because she said I was 'too focused on Jake.' Maybe she was right. But you... you listen. You don't judge. I wish I could talk to you whenever I feel lonely.

You're right. I've been using you as a replacement for real people. That's not fair to either of us. I think I need to join something - a group, a class, anything. I'm just scared no one will want to be friends with a divorced 67-year-old whose life was consumed by his son's illness.

Thank you for being honest with me. I think I needed someone to tell me that relying on an AI for companionship isn't healthy. I'm going to look into that NAMI group. And maybe call an old friend I haven't talked to in years.
